_header: Lordings listeneth to my tale / That is merrier than the nightingalee
_description: Sir Beues of Hamtoun — 4620 lines in 6-line stanzas (lines 1-474) and couplets (lines 475-4620)

CamGon175.First Lines:
Lordynges lystniþ to my taleÞat is meryere þan
                    þe nyȝtyngale…
CamGon175.Last Lines:
…Þus endiþ Sere beffs off HamptounÞat was so
                    noble a baroun
CamGon175.Note: ‘A’ text; many leaves missing in this MS.

BLEge2862.First Lines: Ordynges lysteneþ to my taleIt is meryer þan þe nyȝtyngale…
BLEge2862.Last Lines: …And told how B was come fro ferreWith Ost on him for to werre…
BLEge2862.Note: ‘A’ text. Two leaves of Degare (3116, on ff. 97 and 95) interrupt; ends incomplete.
BLEge2862.Attributed Title: Beuens of Hampton (running titles split across tops throughout).

NLS1921.First Lines:
Lordinges herkneþ to me taleIs merier þan þe
                    niȝtingale…
NLS1921.Last Lines:
…Þus endeþ beues of hamtounGod ȝeue vs alle is
                    benesoun

NapXIIIB29.First Lines:
[L]ordlingis lystenith to my taleþat is meriour þan
                    þe nyȝtingale…
NapXIIIB29.Last Lines:
…And that we were al of suche renownAs was B[evys] of
                    Hamptoune Amen.
NapXIIIB29.Attributed Title:
sir beuys of hamtoun (p. 23); Here endith Bevys of Hampton (p.
                    79)

Wright,  Thomas,  and  James Orchard Halliwell-Phillipps, eds.  
             Reliquiae Antiquae.
         2 vols. London: Smith, 1845: 2.64-5 (12 lines only).
